history.content:
This gets asked periodically, and there's never a good answer. Probably because no one has actually crunched the numbers.

I would expect that the answer to the latter is "no", and the answer to the former is also "no".

More specifically, I would expect much lower drop rates in the summer, because students are more committed to the classes they are taking (harder to find alternatives, tuition is paid per unit so students aren't shopping around, et cetera).

My instinct is that since hiring for TAs is also harder (certainly late hires are quite unlikely), courses are less likely to expand as well.

But I don't know for certain.

(As an aside, I've never heard of anyone actually verifying the 10% rule either. It seems to be one of those "commonly accepted" heuristics, and there's very few anecdotes of "don't trust the 10% rule because it didn't work for me", so it seems like the true drop rate is actually much higher / 10% is a low, conservative bound. So maybe 10% will work for summer courses as well. The point is: I don't think anyone knows.)

children.subject: I might take myself off the 189 course list; just waiting for the instructors to be revealed

history.content: I recently decided that I may want to take courses here over the summer, but since almost a month has passed since enrollment opened, I am currently on the waitlist for both classes that I am considering (188 or 189). Generally for summer courses, are most people able to get off the waitlist? Or is it a 10% rule sort of situation?
history.subject: Summer Course Waitlist
